title: Ombudsman, COA team up on big corruption cases
text:
Ombudsman, COA team up on big corruption cases By Elizabeth Marcelo   
MANILA, Philippines - The Office of the Ombudsman and the Commission on Audit (COA) have agreed to fast-track the investigation of high-profile cases, particularly those involving misuse of at least P100 million worth of public funds. 
In a memorandum of agreement (MOA) dated Feb. 28, a copy of which was released to the media yesterday, the ombudsman and the COA renewed their partnership in the probe of high-profile cases under their Joint Investigation Team (JIT) program launched in 2010. 
The MOA also provides for the creation of “JIT Priority Lane” at ombudsman offices “where the JIT cases shall be immediately filed, docketed and subjected to preliminary investigation.” 
The MOA further provides for the creation of a secretariat that will closely monitor the status of the JIT cases and the progress in each case’s investigation. 
Among the cases to be prioritized under the JIT program are those involving misuse of government funds amounting to at least P100 million or its equivalent in kind or in other currencies. 
Also to be prioritized are graft and corruption cases investigated by Congress as well as other cases “imbued with public interest regardless of the amount.”   
The MOA was signed amid the recent dismissal of the cases before the anti-graft court Sandiganbayan, citing the “inordinate delay” of the ombudsman in conducting its probe. 
Just recently, the Sandiganbayan dismissed the fertilizer fund scam cases against former Parañaque congressman Eduardo Zialcita, former Cebu representatives Antonio Cuenco and Antonio Yapha Jr., former Palawan representative and incumbent Games and Amusement Board chairman Abraham Kahlil Mitra and former senator Lito Lapid after it took the ombudsman several years to finish the investigation on the complaints against them and file the charges before the court.
